Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Central Anatolian Tectonics (CD-CAT): Surface to mantle dynamics during collision to escape
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves an integrated program to study the process of tectonic escape in Central Anatolia. This is the location where this process was first recognized in the 1970s and the PIs make a strong case that this is good place to investigate the temporal and spatial characteristics of this process in the context of a continent-continent collision.

The research builds on previous geophysical and geological studies by many of the PIs in other parts of Turkey (both to the east and west of the planned study area). The research will investigate modern structure through a combination of geophysics and geology. Past history will be reconstructed through studies of elevation, drainage and volcanism. Studies of the Central Anatolian fault are important as this is a major feature that is poorly understood in Anatolian tectonics.

Specifically, the PIs will address the questions:

? What are the plate dynamics from the mantle to the Earth?s surface, the transition from distributed to localized strain in large strike-slip faults, the origin and consequences of magmatism, and the evolution of relief and landscape during development of escape tectonics?
? What are the effects of boundary conditions (collision of Arabian plate to the east, extension of Aegean to the west, subduction of African plate to the south) on the driving forces of tectonic escape?

The study will integrate results of passive seismic experiments; magnetotelluric profiling; geomorphic, structural, and stratigraphic-sedimentological analysis of surface geology and exhumed orogenic crust; geo/thermochronometric determination of temperature-time histories of magmatic, metamorphic, and fault zone rocks and geomorphic features; isotopic fingerprinting and dating of magmatic rocks; and 2D and 3D numerical modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 50 million years of Earth history, the tectonic plate that includes the combined Europe and Asia collided with the Arabian plate to the south. This collision produced the mountains of Turkey, Iran, and the Caucasus countries. Much later, about 10 to 5 million years ago, the central and western Anatolian regions of Turkey began to "escape" by migrating westward toward the Aegean Sea. The process of escape includes a regional size wedge within Turkey that is caught between two large strike-slip faults similar to the San Andreas fault - the North Anatolian fault and East Anatolian fault. The escape process continues today.

This research project investigated the geologic events during the Arabia collision from 50 to 10 million years ago, and the events in the transition to the modern escape as part of a multifaceted and multi-institutional team of researchers. Northern Arizona University (NAU) researchers investigated the timing and origins of faulting, basin development, creation of the Central Anatolia Plateau, and volcanic activity. We then worked with the whole research team from the US, Canada, and Turkey to study the relation of these geologic features to the tectonic evolution of Central Anatolia. The research from the NAU group added important ages, field observations, and chemical data. We also contributed to many new interpretations for the evolution of two major sedimentary basins and associated folds and faults, and the origin of volcanism in four major volcanic areas across Central Anatolia. Major findings include: (1) recognition of how the creation of sedimentary basins was deeply rooted in the evolving plate collision; (2) linking of landscape evolution, including initial development of the high plateau of Central Anatolia, to the stages of continental collision; and (3) interpretation of the volcanic history of Central Anatolia in the context of evolving interactions between the two plates during and after collision. For the last finding, we concluded that volcanism since 12 million years ago was linked to the tectonic evolution of Turkey, while locally individual volcanoes were related to active faulting and basin development.

The overall result of our work is recognition that deformation and volcanism occurred in two stages during collision across central to eastern Anatolia between 50 and 20 million years ago, and that the transition to escape also occurred in two stages, the first of which overlapped with the second collision stage. The proposed tectonic stages have, in turn, been shown to reflect changes deeper within Earth's interior, those associated with evolving interactions between the Eurasian and Arabian plates. The better understanding of deep Earth processes was made possible by our detailed studies of volcanic rocks, combined with our colleagues who used seismic waves from earthquakes around the Earth to study the structure of the deep Earth.

This project resulted in eight peer-review publications and numerous conference presentations, with another 3 - 4 papers in preparation. It was the focus of training and professional development for two PhD and two MS students. Their skills in geologic analyses, literature review, and critical thinking and interpretations were advanced as a result of this project. All students completed their graduate degrees and are now employed in geoscience-related fields. The project was also the focal point for an international collaboration, the findings of which have been widely shared.
